name: NPR
text:
ICYMI: A federal judge has ordered the Denver Police Department not to use chemical weapons or projectiles against peaceful protesters.

â€œThe Denver Police Department has failed in its duty to police its own." https://t.co/4jeFpy3Ngc

name: NPR
text: ICYMI: The two Buffalo Police officers seen shoving an elderly protester to the ground as their fellow officers walk past have been charged with second-degree assault. https://t.co/EDEEsIBDHD

name: NPR
text: Black America has been hit harder by the virus and job losses. And then there's the other pandemic, as the lawyer for George Floyd's family put it: systemic racism and discrimination. https://t.co/NuSIhJGzi7

name: NPR
text:
Comedian W. Kamau Bell says he's working overtime these days. "Black people of all jobs get asked to explain racism to white people, whether that's in their job description or not," he says. 

"Well, it happens to be my job description."
https://t.co/BSObbfRx0Y

name: NPR
text:
All 4 officers involved in George Floyd's killing are behind bars. 

But, "it's ... like a Band-Aid being put over a big gaping open wound," one woman says. 

That's why she and so many others gather at the place where he was killed. To remember. To heal. https://t.co/N9IIAMlRy8

name: NPR
text:
Doctors are attributing MIS-C to complications linked to COVID-19. But they're still trying to figure out when kids are getting it.

"Is this acute viral? Is this post-infectious? Is it a combination?" asks one expert. https://t.co/Aznvpo8En0

name: NPR
text:
Boat living can be especially claustrophobic amid a pandemic, but it also offers the U.K.'s estimated 15,000 boat-dwellers an escape from city life.

"As it turned out," one says, "living on a boat, it's kind of the ideal way to have to isolate."
 https://t.co/1EwzhTNAnn

name: NPR
text:
Payday lenders market themselves as a quick financial fix by offering quick cash online or in storefronts â€” but often lead borrowers into unpayable debt.

This debt trap can lead to damaged credit, bankruptcy and even worse health outcomes. @hereandnow
https://t.co/P3KUnJ42eF

name: NPR
text:
All 50 states have begun the process of easing restrictions on businesses. We're tracking how each state is reopening.

West: https://t.co/RhlKkuNK5I
Midwest: https://t.co/gOx5WCARCo
South: https://t.co/NaQfQsjhFD
Northeast: https://t.co/uCW6ZZfoCr

https://t.co/XRcUe5OtEO

name: NPR
text:
Aziz Asmar painted a mural of George Floyd in war-torn Idlib in Syria. 

"We have a humanitarian duty to sympathize with all the oppressed in the world," he says. 

Here's how people around the world are honoring black lives and demanding racial equality:
https://t.co/T3G5AJuCgq

name: NPR
text:
U.S. airlines are boosting their flight schedules in preparation for the summer after experiencing an increase in customer demand, but returning to 2019 travel numbers will take years, according to an airline executive.
https://t.co/bIYufAKDA7

name: NPR
text:
Dozens of public health and disease experts have signed an open letter in support of the nationwide anti-racism protests.

"White supremacy is a lethal public health issue that predates and contributes to COVID-19," they wrote.
https://t.co/yFjEN5VlVS

name: NPR
text:
On Monday, Joe Biden will speak in-person to George Floyd's family.

President Trump will hold a roundtable with law enforcement at the White House. 

These actions couldn't better sum up the two candidates' positions â€” and the bets they're making to win. https://t.co/NYrSCQZlUV

name: NPR
text:
A 2014 study from the U.S Army offers an alarming glimpse into how tear gas could escalate the pandemic: Recruits who were exposed to it during training were more likely to get sick with respiratory illnesses. 
 https://t.co/qzDycoRl3b

name: NPR
text:
Democrats will unveil the Justice in Policing Act of 2020 on Monday. Here's what it proposes: 

â€” Bans on the usage of choke-holds and no-knock warrants

â€” Lower legal standards to pursue police misconduct

â€” A national registry to track police misconduct https://t.co/TjpNbFDpHq

name: NPR
text:
"Qualified immunity" has shielded police and other government officials from lawsuits over their conduct.

Now, two Supreme Court justices â€” the most liberal and the most conservative â€” are calling for a re-examination of the doctrine. https://t.co/NDaxDSMCyM

name: NPR
text:
Indians can now dine out, shop in malls and pray at religious sites for the first time in over two months. 

But the reopening of the world's largest lockdown comes as the country records its biggest spike in new coronavirus cases in a single day. https://t.co/7EBgvnXrUa

name: NPR
text:
The head of The New York Times editorial page, James Bennet, has resigned over a controversial opinion piece calling for federal troops to be deployed to quell rioters. 

But his tenure as editor, the publication says, was "marked by several missteps." https://t.co/CyDRnIMK0E

name: NPR
text:
They're usually white, over 50 years old, married, don't have a college degree, and would be considered suburban "soccer moms."

And they could help decide this year's presidential election. https://t.co/AGu7IZlVMM

name: NPR
text:
Last week, NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell said the league was "wrong for not listening to NFL players earlier" on issues of race and oppression.

President Trump, once again, has something to say about the NFL and "disrespecting" the flag. https://t.co/FAGd4dpQjZ

name: NPR
text: JUST IN: The National Bureau of Economic Research has declared that the U.S. started a recession in March, pointing to the "unprecedented magnitude of the decline in employment and production" across the economy. https://t.co/wDa3IenMIL

name: NPR
text:
Jesse Jackson and Josie Johnson have been prominent civil rights leaders since 1960 and before â€” and they see change happening. 

"The marchers are full of hope," says Jackson. "They believe something can happen. On the move, we're not going backwards." https://t.co/uhN88sus6f

name: NPR
text:
Mourners are gathering for a final public memorial to George Floyd in his hometown of Houston for a six-hour viewing at The Fountain of Praise Church. 

His killing has sparked global protests over police mistreatment of communities of color. https://t.co/khDrmG3luZ

name: NPR
text:
House and Senate Democrats have unveiled the Justice in Policing Act, meant to overhaul policing by banning the usage of choke-holds and no-knock warrants, as well as create a national registry to track police misconduct. 

Read the bill here ðŸ‘‡ https://t.co/vCViDhuhiQ

name: NPR
text:
In China, the coronavirus evaporated tens of millions of urban and factory jobs. 

Now, many of China's unemployed are returning to rural villages for agricultural work, endangering the country's plan to eradicate rural poverty by the end of 2020. https://t.co/4904DVRah7
